stem: The charge nurse is reviewing the care plan for a patient admitted with a hemorrhagic stroke. Which nursing interventions should be included to manage the patient's increased intracranial pressure (ICP)? Select all that apply.

options.text: Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees.
options.feedback: Correct. Elevating the head of the bed promotes venous drainage.

options.text: Cluster nursing activities to allow for longer periods of rest.
options.feedback: Incorrect. Clustering activities can increase ICP due to stimulation.

options.text: Maintain the patient in a Trendelenburg position.
options.feedback: Incorrect. Trendelenburg increases blood flow to the brain and elevates ICP.
Correct. A neutral head position prevents jugular vein compression.
Correct. Stool softeners prevent straining, which can increase ICP.
Incorrect. Hypotonic solutions can worsen cerebral edema.
Correct. Frequent neuro checks are essential for early detection of changes.

options.text: Maintain a calm and quiet environment.
options.feedback: Correct. Reducing external stimuli helps manage ICP.

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed to 30 degrees promotes venous drainage from the brain, reducing ICP. Maintaining a neutral head position prevents compression of the jugular veins, which can impede venous outflow and increase ICP. Administering stool softeners prevents straining during bowel movements, which can increase ICP. Closely monitoring neurological status allows for early detection of changes in ICP and timely intervention. Maintaining a calm and quiet environment reduces external stimuli that can exacerbate ICP.

mnemonic.title: ICP Management
mnemonic.expansion: Elevate Head, Neutral Head, Stool Softeners, Neuro Checks, Quiet Environment

rationale.incorrect: Clustering nursing activities can increase ICP due to cumulative stimulation. Frequent suctioning can also increase ICP and should be reserved for when absolutely necessary. Encouraging coughing can significantly increase ICP due to increased intrathoracic and intra-abdominal pressure. Placing the patient in the Trendelenburg position increases blood flow to the brain and elevates ICP. Administering hypotonic solutions can lead to cerebral edema, worsening ICP.

questionTrap.trap: Many students focus on individual ICP-reducing interventions but fail to recognize the importance of a holistic approach that minimizes stimuli and promotes venous drainage.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Consider the cumulative effect of nursing actions on ICP and prioritize interventions that minimize stimulation and facilitate venous outflow.

clinicalPearls: Early recognition and management of increased ICP are crucial to prevent secondary brain injury.
Neurological assessments should be performed frequently and consistently to detect subtle changes.
Maintaining cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is essential in patients with increased ICP.

itemContext.sbar: S: Mr. Smith, 68-year-old male, admitted at 03:00 with a hemorrhagic stroke. Sudden onset of left-sided weakness and severe headache at home. B: History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, currently on lisinopril and atorvastatin. Denies smoking. A: GCS is currently 10 (E2, V3, M5). Right pupil is sluggish, left pupil is reactive. BP is 180/100, HR is 92, RR is 24, SpO2 is 94% on 2L NC. ICP monitoring initiated, current ICP is 22 mmHg. Receiving IV fluids at 75 mL/hr. 04:00 CT scan confirmed right parietal hemorrhage. O: We need to manage his ICP. Orders include mannitol if ICP >25 mmHg and elevating the head of the bed. Monitor neuro status closely. The family is very anxious and requested an update.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
MedicationDoseRouteFrequencyLast Administered
Lisinopril20 mgPODaily08:00
Atorvastatin40 mgPODaily08:00
Acetaminophen650 mgPRQ4H PRN for headacheN/A
Mannitol0.25 g/kgIVPRN for ICP > 25 mmHgN/A
